name: Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure

reviews.review_text: Really fun game. Played a lot of it on PSP back a few years ago but never actually owned the game until now. Nice artstyle and fun zelda-esque gameplay. The game also runs locked at 30fps (I think but im not entirely sure) so if you're the kind of person that wines about 30fps then you might want to hold out until someone unlocks the framerate. Otherwise Gurumin is A cheap, fun RPG from the creators of Ys. Pick it up if you're a fan of Zelda or games like it.  The game has a pretty choppy/weird performance for a lot of people (including me). Its annoying at times but it isn't much of a bother. (However if this is something that bothers you, You might want to wait for a patch or a mod that fixes it or try turning off Vsync. Which fixed the problem for a lot of people)  EDIT: A little side note. The game has trading cards marked in the steam store, However the game does not have any trading cards at the moment. They'll probably be added in a few days or so though.  EDIT 2: The game has recieved an update which adds WASD to the control scheme.  TL;DR - Fun Zelda-like game. However is held down by Questionable control scheme and 30fps lock.  8/10

A fun, super-charming 3D action game. You get a bunch of different headgear to serve as equipment, with some shared and some unique benefits, like the gas mask protects from poison gas, goggles from water damage, etc. Headgear can be leveled up to improve their effects and add new ones like damage reduction and damage multipliers. You only have a drill as a weapon, with three exchangeable elemental parts but they all play the mostly the same aside from some enemies being weak to different elements. There's a bunch of special moves you unlock through buying parts for your drill and they're all easy enough to perform.  The gameplay is separated into short dungeon crawls, with no area being any longer than twenty minutes or so. Each area has two regular stages, then a boss, then two more 'secret' stages that can be unlocked by solving some type of riddle. There's enough stages to give the game a solid length and it ends before becoming tedious.  Being a 3D action/platformer, the camera control can be a bit finicky, especially since the game doesn't an option to map the right analog stick on the controller as camera control, instead defaulting to the shoulder bumpers. You get used to it after a while though, and it's never too big of a problem. The first platforming section with water is probably the worst in the game for various reasons, so don't fear if you flub it up a bunch. There's not a ton of precise platforming here. Otherwise, the game controls well. Parin moves fast and attacks fast. If you've played previous Falcom games, you already know they know how to do fast-paced action really well. The music and sound effects are good, too, as you'd expect from a Falcom game.  As for the story/voice acting stuff, it's bleh and generic for the most part, but the lead character has a good dub and the game has a ton of little charming touches that overshadow the problems. NPC dialogue is pretty fun and you can examine a bunch of stuff in-game and Parin will comment on it. The game's artstlye has aged really well, so even though it's technically unimpressive, the game never really looks bad due to a strong stylistic foundation.  For those that like to replay/master rank games, there's a ton here, like multiple unlockable difficulties and extra headgear/costumes to find and even a secret playable character. It you don't care about that kind of thing, it can be safely ignored without hurting your experience.   As for the port, it's a bit of a mixed bag at this point. I'd played it 1080p, and there was a constant white line along the top of the screen, only really noticeable during the letterboxed cinematics but it's there. There's also appears to be issues with new game+ stuff unlocking incorrectly, as I had one of the extras upon starting up a new game+, but it seemed to have disappeared forever after quitting the game and reloading. I imagine these types of bugs will be fixed in the near future.  In short, if you're looking for a fast-paced, light-hearted 3D action game, Gurumin is what you're looking for, especially considering how few likeminded games like this there are available on PC.

This game is absolutely sweet. It's pretty much a rated E for everyone, obviously a kids game, but I'm sure you'll enjoy the charm of this game regardless of age. It reminds me a bit of those PS1 action platformers like crash bandicoot and spyro and such. Probably because of the graphics quality and style.  While it looks a bit low poly, the graphics is good enough for what it does, and the style makes up for it. It all look pretty cute. The quality on sound effects and music is quite good.  The action platforming is also quite nice, not too easy, and certainly not too diffcult.  The bosses in the game pack quite a punch, but by the first boss you'll probably have figured out how to dodge those.  All 'n all, a great game for anyone that loves 3d action platformers.

What a light hearted rpg..althought there are aspects to make it hard-cored too. Lots of things about this game are fun..the funny monsters, the interesting dungeons, and the storyline. Don't let the cutie graphics turn you off. If your a hard core rpger, there is also collection goals in each level, and ranking scores. There are also different levels of difficulty if you find easy too..well easy. If you like really hard core rpg's, this game might not be for you, but if you want a light hearted storyline with some collecting of things on dungeons with secret passages and puzzels, try this one out.

For those who remember old school ps3/psp action adventrure games, this will be one for you. Took me about 6 hours to complete - granted i did rush through some dungeons. I would say it is worth its price despite the cheesy plot and basic interface. What it lacks in aesthetics, it makes up for with satisfying gameplay. Reccommended to play with a controller to get the proper experience.
playing this makes me wish my psp was still working so i could play patapon and/or loco roco 10/10

It's crazy that this game isn't more popular. I ran into this because I'm a big Falcom fan, but the appeal is wider than that.  All of y'all clamoring for a return to form for classic-style platormers/action games that are impatient to play the likes of Poi, A Hat in Time, and Yooka-Laylee? Look no further. This is your jam. You want a new Goemon game? Just pretend Parin is Ebisumaru and you'll feel it. You'll  feel  it, son.  One look at the style of the game from its screenshots and you will not be surprised to hear me say the controls feel clunky at first. You need to stick with it, though! It very quickly becomes comfortable. On a scale from 'any modern Sega game' to 'dat mario gamefeel' I'd rate it a solid 'Resident Evil 4.'  When this comes out for 3DS, I'll be buying it and playing it all over again.
Really cute game. The story deserves little award, but the world and characters inhabiting it are very memorable! It's very fun to play!

Sorry for my english. A very very very cute game. In my opinion, it has similar magic like thing like Ni no Kuni, a very friendly beautiful game, and when playing it make me to remember when I was a child.

This game single-handedly turned me into a weeb. Zelda + a 3D platformer + Kawaii desu crap out the wazoo = Gurumin This chick can see monsters no one else can. Kick the bad monsters' asses to save the good monsters, using some kinda drill-on-a-stick you pull outta the ground excalibur/master sword style, and solve some puzzles while you're at it. Has a neat little system where if you time your attacks to the beat of the music, you get a critical hit.
Everything the positive reviewers say is true, no reason to repeat it all here. Developers should get more attention and money for future projects.

I really wanted to love this game but the only redeeming quality is the n64 like gameplay (3d platforming and combat). The characters, cutscenes, voice acting, music, general story/script/writing/climax, ect is bad to awful. So much so, that it's difficult to get through due to the amount of cringe.

One thing everyone should be aware of before buying is that this is a port of a psp  But if you can get over the controls being a bit wobbly, the camera being a bit wobbly, and the graphics not being the best  Theres an absolute gem of a game in here :)  The voice acting shines  The world feels magical  The soundtrack is amazing  And the game is just filled with personailty  If you like to binge on action/rpgs with light puzzle mechanics (Classic zelda esque puzzles)  You will likely get your moneys worth from this :)

This is the third time i buy and play this game, and it's still worth it!  This game is a charming little action adventure from Falcom, with a light story, some really goofy characters and a nice colorful artstyle. Most of the gameplay is simple but addicting, it's a nice little fighting system with some basic combo's, and some expandable or upgradable attacks. There are about 25 levels and some bosses to complete plus some minigames, and if you want to collect all outfits, upgrade all items, and get S+ ratings on every level, there's plenty of playing time.  If you buy this, ( and yes, i recommend you do! ) you should try to play it with a controller (supported), because the keyboard and mouse dragging options are not perfect for this game, in my opinion.  Aside from that, absolutely love this game!
Fun game with puzzles and action and the like :)) lovable characters and surprising story twist
There aren't enough mods in the world to make skyrim this moe

Gurumin is an action platformer developed by Falcom in 2003. The project was helmed by the same group who made Zwei but is about a girl who uses a drill to defeat enemies and dig through structures instead of using a partner to shoot magic and relies on eating to boost stats. This title was also made when Nihon Falcom was sorta in a rut and didn't find financial success to run on until Sora no Kiseki Second Chapter. This really shows now adays as Gurumin looks no better than a N64 game with improved textures to dabble with.   The game's still fun, albeit very very simple. The music is kinda boring, the enemies are slow and easy, the map design is kinda rudamentary. All and all this seems like a simple game whipped up by a studio and dev team to just clear some technical checkpoints. This is a Banjo Kazooie/Mario 64/Ape Escape/Crash Bandicoot clone that while fun is just lacking in so many areas.   It's charming, cheap, and worth a try. Give it a whirl if you like the team behind it, but I wouldn't really say get it if you're looking to revist the era where action platformers dominated the market because this is not the next Jet Force Gemini.

Just started playing the Steam port but it seems to be evertyhing I loved about the PSP game and more. The original version was a hidden gem in the PSP library so getting a PC port for a third of the original's asking price is a bargain! Plus it works perfectly well with an Xbox controller. If you like Zelda games or any other Action RPG, you owe it to yourself to try Gurumin!
Awesome Action RPG from Nihon Falcom. Rock Solid OST. Xenogears like platforming was so feels. Thanks Mastiff.
Good paced game!  So cute!

I would not recommend this game and there is one reason to it, for me it was like having a cat.Yes you will enjoy having it in the beginning but later on you wont be enjoying it that much.The game has graphics equal to most PS2 era games, a predictable,linear and childish story.If you are 13 or under, go for it, you might enjoy it.If you're 14 or older then its just a 'fun' game to play when you got nothing else to do.Overall if you like games that are easy to play and master this is a game for you.If not then Gurumin is not the game you're looking for.

Cute spunky girl protagonist with sick smokin' combat style. The controls are smooth as butter and the combat is satisfying and fun. It's as cute and silly as the art style would have you believe, and the story doesn't get in the way of the cool action.

Falcom knows how to make fun and addicting games, and this is no exception. A very heartwarming story, charming characters, engaging gameplay, excellent soundtrack and many extras to unlock make this game a very unique experience. Definitely a must play for every Falcom fan.

It starts out as an incredibly easy game, but the difficulty ramps up quickly. So, if you are bored in level 1, try to stick with it. I do agree that Hard should come unlocked  This game is full of charm, and there's lots of cuteness. Characters look at each-other when present, the main character will do poses like Sonic would do when you are idle, but never punishes you for it. There are lots of animation flourishes, but they don't get in the way of gameplay. They are done right because they aren't something that is player-initiated. There's also victory dances. Not enough games have victory dances. I miss that about Final Fantasy  The combat control is excellent. I can't tell if the 3D platforming is good or not due to the nature of 3D platforming. That part is frustrating. You don't feel like you have as much control of the character as you do in combat. Still, there's more combat than platforming, and the game is very lenient on screw-ups when you do platforming  As a budget game, I give this game a definite yes. I even say that it's worth above the budget level, but people may not buy it at more than $20. This feels like a Playstation-era game, and plays like one of the good ones.  There's also something Charlie Brown-esque about the voices that I kind-of like. It's nicely different than dubbed anime characters almost always having either that WWE or Wonder Woman voice, especially children. The awkward voicing kind-of works in this game, even though they could have acted some lines better when the lead character makes certain facial expressions  I also find the replay value of this game to be high. I hardly want to replay games, but I'm going another round at the hard difficulty. I don't do this often

MUH DRILLZ!  I'll get straight to the point: this game will definitely drill its way into your heart. *pause for laughter or groans*  *ahem* now that I have you either groaning from the pun or laughing your ♥♥♥ off, I'll start the real review.  This game comes to steam years later from the initial release in japan back in 2004, which got ported to PSP in June of 2006, made a north american appearance in 2007, and got an original PC release worldwide on steam. From my point of view, everything about this game is great, with just a few minor complaints I have, which I will get to in this review.  Graphics: 9/10 - The graphics remind me of early playstation games such as Brave Fencer Musashi. They get the job done, vibrant, and great use of color. You can also tell it makes great use of cell-shading, but the characters do tend to look a little too simplistic. Overall, however, this game looks great.  Gameplay: 9.5/10 - The game plays very well, and that's as much as I can say about it right now as I've only just started playing this game. I will definitely update when the time comes, but one minor complaint: so far, I haven't really run into any boss fights. EDIT: Just ran into my first boss fight, and lemmie tell ya, they can really drill it to ya -pause again for laughs or groans-. They're challenging, but fair. It at least gives you time to use healing items and not have them clobber you as you do so. Overall, the boss fights are great and vibrant.  Controls: 8/10 - Here's where I have to make a few complaints about controls here. Some of the moves aren't very clear on what to do, especially if you're using a gamepad (or xbox 360/XBOne controller) for control. The instructions are strictly PC oriented with no mention of what to do with the gamepad. I would complain about it more, if it weren't for the fact that you learn pretty quickly what buttons do what move, so it's no big issue and the controls can be customized*.  However, the controls do the job well, either way. The jump controls are interesting, but can get a little frustrating, especially having to make platform jumps. Fortunately, the shadow effects will help you, and you can angle the camera any way you please (right stick for xbox 360 controllers). The inclusion of timed hits to the beat of the music with the beat bar displayed on screen is a wonderful addition. If you've mastered Crypt of the Necrodancer, you'll definitely find that getting critical hits via the beat of the music to be very easy and fun.  Sound: 9/10 - The music, even though you can tell it's synthesizer, is VERY well done. The english voice acting is a bit cheesy, but works anyways. The music is upbeat and well composed, in my opinion. You'll need to get that tempo down if you want to do critical hit damage, but the timing of each beat is precise and works very well.  Overall: 9.25/10 - This game is definitely a title for platform gamers to really dig into -pause for groans or laughter-. Hopefully, we'll see some patches released to fix some of the issues, but overall, I recommend this game for anyone who loves a good platform game.   *At least the options to do that are up, but I've seen some forum posts about the game not running because options got changed. Hopefully, this gets patched soon, as I did suffer the same thing when I tried to change around a few options. Should you find your game not starting up, just hit the restore defaults button on the windows menu screen that comes up and it'll start normally again. I have successfully changed a few options after having do to this, but kept it to just force feedback and maybe one other thing.

There was a very generous campaign behind this game during its time on Greenlight, which allowed me to snag a copy of the game for free. Because of that, I can't complain too much, especially being that this is a very old title and therefore is bound to have issues here and there.   That being said, the framerate is rather choppy, and the game seems to crash in strange ways for me. For instance: Talking to the NPC in the starting town that gives you the goggles caused my video driver to crash (using AMD 7970HD GPU). Holding the spacebar caused my character to jump in place, or rather, cause the jumping animation to loop and the jumping sound effect to play rapidly without the character actually leaving the ground. I do wish there was a way to bring the game upto 60FPS proper; Applications such as fraps will report 60 FPS, but this doesn't seem to actually be the case (menus run at that framerate, but in-game animations do not, according to what I've read).   Seems theres still a few bugs to work out. If you have the game already, there's generally no reason to be pessimistic; Its visually charming, and playthroughs seem to imply that its a rather fun time. But unfortunately, I wouldn't know as I can't get the goggles, as explained earlier in this post.  TL;DR: If you have it already, great. If you're contemplating a purchase, dont; at least, not yet. Give them a little more time to debug and work things out.

So this game is a game that i feel like i'm playing a pc port of a Dreamcast game or Gamecube. now when i say this  I'm not being negitive becuae it like games from that era. and saying that that means the games arn't that perfect. some things phase throught objects, and the jumping is ok (what i mean by that is when you jump into a wall the game gets kinda dumb) and that you can't jump over object. the combat is nice and i enjoy it. but some special moves get in the way of basic combat. And the story is kinda saterday morning cartoon worth being shallow but well done. the games a light hearted fun adventure for people of most tastes. if your looking for a game to sink a couple hour in for a weekend go ahead this game i really recemond. buy it!. 7/10 FYI POCO IS THE DANCE MASTER

I really wish we had more games like this. A really cute, harmless 3D platformer that really captures that feel of N64/PS1 era games. The game was originally released back in 2004 and then the PSP a few years later, but I still think it has this old-school charm that you don't see in most games these days.   I still have a ways to go before finishing the game completely, but from what I've played thus far? It's a very relaxing a mellow experience that feels really enjoyable and has a classic-anime flavor to it.

A monster of a cute game.  Hack N' Slash styled adventure that is family friendly.  I hear the PSP version is abit better. I had a PSP years ago, however my itty bitty eye balls can't stand hand held console screens anymore, 50 inch screens for me, thanks.
